Award.AwardTitle: Spin Dynamics of Photogenerated Multi-Spin Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Michael R. Wasielewski of the Department of Chemistry at Northwestern University is developing new molecules with controllable spin transport properties. These molecules target new information processing strategies and take advantage of the quantum nature of electron spin. This work may lead to advanced computer technologies with broad applications throughout society. The use of organic materials and bio-inspired approaches to achieve this goal offers the possibility of developing new structures that are not only versatile, but are cost effective and environmentally benign as well. The group has an ongoing relationship with local middle and high schools through a partnership with the Office of STEM Education Partnership (OSEP) at Northwestern University. Working with OSEP, they are developing educational materials useful in teaching and for incorporating research into learning and education. Additionally, regular 1-2 day professional development workshops are held and week-long job shadowing experiences for teachers are implemented to provide a multiplier effect in connecting students to the rich learning resources at Northwestern University.

Fast photo-initiated electron transfer within covalently-linked organic donor-acceptor molecules having specific donor-acceptor distances and orientations results in the formation of spin-correlated radical pairs (SCRPs) having well-defined initial spin configurations and magnetic interactions. Time-resolved electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and pulse-EPR spectroscopy are used to manipulate, control, and observe these coherent spin states. This new research investigates how spin sharing over multiple radical sites influences coherence dephasing in SCRPs; how electron transfer from a photo-excited stable radical to a distant site affects spin coherence; how coherent spin states can be propagated over long intramolecular distances using SCRPs; and how a photo-generated SCRP can produce transient spin frustration and propagate spin coherence within a three-fold symmetric molecular system. The project lies at the interface of organic, physical, and materials chemistry, and is therefore well suited to the education of scientists at all levels. This group is also well-positioned to provide the highest level of education and training for students underrepresented in science. Outreach activities involving K-12 students and their teachers are part of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Preparing physical qubits in specific initial quantum states is essential for their use in quantum information science. Sub-nanosecond photoinduced electron transfer in a structurally well-defined molecular donor-acceptor system can be used to produce an entangled spin qubit (radical) pair (SQP) in a pure initial singlet state fulfilling this criterion. Photogenerated spin-entangled SQPs occur in diverse molecular systems, including photosynthetic reaction center proteins, electron donors and acceptors in micelles, covalent fixed-distance donor-acceptor molecules, cryptochromes implicated in the mechanism of the avian compass and donor-acceptor systems that are part of DNA hairpin structures. Recently, it has been recognized that spin-entangled SQPs produced by ultrafast electron transfer can be used to implement 2-qubit quantum information protocols, and to probe the nature of quantum measurement in molecular systems.

This NSF-sponsored research project developed an understanding of how spin coherences can be generated, maintained and propagated in organic molecular systems. Manipulating these coherences is important for developing molecular systems for quantum information processing. Photo-driven electron transfer is used to generate spin qubit pairs in structurally well-defined covalent donor-acceptor molecules. We investigated several aspects of spin coherence between multiple spins within these systems: 1) observation of zero quantum coherence in the entangled spin qubits; 2) the influence of spin sharing over multiple qubit sites on coherence dephasing; 3) spin coherence transfer by photoexcitation of a stable radical; 4) observation of zero quantum coherence transfer by photoexcitation of a radical that comprises the spin qubit pair; 5) quantum teleportation of spin states by reduction of a stable radical covalently linked to an entangled spin qubit pair; and 6) the relationship between spin coherence and photo-driven spin frustration. The results of this project were reported in 24 journal publications and 4 Ph.D. theses.

Broader Impacts: The Wasielewski Group offers multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary education, a global network of colleagues and peers, and sense of responsibility to the world that the students develop, which they will carry forward into the workforce. Graduate education in the Wasielewski group focuses on an integrated approach that encourages students to be problem solvers. The students are taught to prepare complex molecules and at the same time learn the physical techniques necessary to answer the questions that are being addressed in their research. Graduate students Noah Horwitz, Yilei Wu, Brandon Rugg, and Jordan Nelson successfully defended their Ph.D. dissertations.

Our long-time effort to place women in scientific careers continues with 35% of the current research group being female. In the past five years, four women from the Wasielewski group have obtained faculty positions at major research universities and high-quality four-year colleges. We continue to actively recruit and mentor women scientists to pursue a variety of careers within STEM and related fields. For example, women from the Wasielewski Group founded and remain very active in the organization Women in Science and Engineering Research (WISER) that seeks to support women in chemistry and related fields as they advance through graduate school and pursue fulfilling professional careers.

Undergraduate research education has been and continues to be an important part of the Wasielewski group research program. We typically have three undergraduate researchers in residence. Research funds obtained through the NSF are leveraged by additional funds provided by Northwestern to support undergraduate research. Undergraduate Daniel Abia performed research on this project.

We co-organized an NSF-sponsored workshop on Quantum Information and Chemistry that was held November 14-15, 2016 in Arlington, VA. The workshop was attended by investigators from academia, industry, and national labs in addition to several government agencies.  A wide-ranging discussion was held on a variety of issues relating to how chemistry can contribute to advancing the field of quantum information, and how recent advances in quantum information can impact chemistry.  The workshop report was published in early 2017.

We continued our collaboration with the Northwestern Office for STEM Education Partnership (OSEP) to develop and execute novel, impactful programs to promote awareness of the importance of science. The Center has created two successful, ongoing programs in K-12 education: 1) teacher professional development workshops and 2) informal STEM learning.

We also continued our worldwide collaborations with multiple universities, government laboratories, and research centers. We hosted several collaborative stays for graduate students and principal investigators from the U.K., Sweden, Germany, Israel, Japan, and China during the term of this project.
